API Reference¶

Markio is very simple to use. Users may want to use the markio.parse() and markio.parse_string() functions

>>> import markio
>>> parsed = makrio.parse('hello-person.markio')
>>> parsed.title
'Hello Person'

The parsed output is an instance of the markio.Markio. See the documentation bellow.

markio.parse(file, extra=None)[source]¶

Parse the given markio file.

If it is a real file in the filesystem, the parser will look for supplementary data in adjacent files such as answer keys, lang files, etc.

Parameters:
  • file – A string with a path to a markio file or a file object.
  • extra – A dictionary mapping fragment paths to files (or file paths) that hold that data.
markio.parse_string(text, extra={})[source]¶

Parse trees¶

The parse tree root node is an instance of markio.Markio. This structure can be initialized either as the result of markio.parse() and markio.parse_string(), or it can be constructed manually as in the following example

>>> markio = Markio("Example question", author="Me")

We can also add data by directly writing in the attributes

>>> markio.short_description = "A simple example"
>>> markio.description = "Long description paragraph in markdown."

The “answer key” and “placeholder” sections are just a dictionaries mapping programming languages to their corresponding source

>>> markio.answer_key['python'] = 'print("hello world")'
>>> markio.placeholder['python'] = '# type you python code here'

Finally, translations are accessed as indexes

>>> markio['pt_BR'].placeholder['python'] = '# digite seu código aqui'

We can either pretty-print the resulting structure or generate the corresponding markio source

>>> markio.pprint()
{'answer_key': {'python': 'print("hello world")'},
 'author': 'Me',
 'description': 'Long description paragraph in markdown.',
 'placeholder': {'python': '# type you python code here'},
 'short_description': 'A simple example',
 'title': 'Example question',
 'translations': {'pt_BR': {'placeholder': {'python': '# digite seu código '
                                                      'aqui'}}}}
>>> print(markio.source())
Example question
================

    Author: Me

A simple example


Description
-----------

Long description paragraph in markdown.


Answer Key (python)
-------------------

    print("hello world")


Placeholder (python)
--------------------

    # type you python code here

Placeholder (pt_BR, python)
---------------------------

    # digite seu código aqui

Markio class API reference¶

class markio.Markio(**kwds)[source]¶
add_answer_key(source, lang)[source]¶

Adds a new answer key source for a given programming language lang.

add_placeholder(source, lang=None, i18n=None)[source]¶

Adds a new placeholder text for a given programming language lang. If i18n is given, it will add the placeholder in a translation section.

copy()[source]¶

Return a deep copy.

iter_translations()[source]¶

Iterate over all pairs of (lang, markio).

pprint(file=None, **kwds)[source]¶

Pretty print Markio structure.

source()[source]¶

Renders the source code equivalent to the markio structure.
